texts.text-14-9: "Fear, my shadow?" replied Elena, proudly. "I am ready to run!"

texts.text-14-11: On your marks, get set, go!

texts.text-25-2: The Sun is a star, a ball of explosive gases.
texts.text-25-3: It is the natural source of light and heat for the Earth.
texts.text-25-5: Most of the objects we see do not have their own light.
texts.text-25-6: We can see them because they receive it from a luminous body.
texts.text-25-4: There are other sources of light that are artificial, such as electric lamps or candles.
texts.text-25-7: BODIES AND THEIR RELATIONSHIP WITH LIGHT
texts.text-25-8: Bodies can be classified as opaque, translucent, and transparent.
texts.text-25-9: Opaque bodies do not allow light to pass through and produce a shadow, as happens with cardboard.
texts.text-25-10: Translucent bodies allow the passage of light, but it is not possible to see clearly through them.
texts.text-25-11: Some examples are frosted glass and nylon.
texts.text-25-12: The transparent ones allow the passage of light and can be seen through clearly, just as with the glass of some windows or the lenses' crystal.
texts.text-25-14: The shadows produced by sunlight vary in shape throughout the day.
texts.text-25-15: In the morning, shadows are elongated, at noon they shorten or disappear, and in the late afternoon, they become elongated again.
texts.text-25-16: Sunlight propagates in a straight line; this explains the deformation of the shadow.
texts.text-25-17: *Text prepared by ProLEE for this notebook from various encyclopedic sources.

texts.text-26-9: Opaque bodies do not allow the passage of light.
texts.text-26-11: Opaque bodies let the light pass through.
texts.text-26-12: Opaque bodies obstruct the passage of light.

texts.sectioneli5-10-0: Think about what you like to do the most when you're not in class, like playing, drawing, or inventing stories. Then, draw it and describe it in the space you have, so you can share how fun it is for you.
texts.sectioneli5-10-1: In this activity, you can draw and write about the things you do very well. It's like telling someone about your superpowers, as if you were a hero in what you like and are good at doing.
texts.sectioneli5-12-0: Elena has a special little companion when she runs, but it is not a person, a pet, or an athlete. This little friend only appears if there is light. Do you know who it is? It's her shadow because it can only be seen when there is light to illuminate it.
texts.sectioneli5-13-0: Elena is a girl who loves to run races. She races with her brother, her dog, and even with her turtle. She likes running a lot, more than anything else. One day, her parents tell her that she has to spend the afternoon with her grandfather Enrique, but she doesn't want to because she thinks she will get bored. In the end, she discovers that there are fabulous things at her grandfather's house, like a very beautiful garden, and she understands that playing and spending time with her grandfather can also be fun.
texts.sectioneli5-13-1: Elena loves to run and compete in races. She runs with her little brother who still crawls and says 'I won!' because she beats him. But when she runs with her dog, she says 'I lost!' because the dog is faster. Elena really likes races because she finds them fun.
texts.sectioneli5-13-2: Elena ran races for fun and challenged everyone. One day she ran against her turtle and won, but when she ran against her dad, she lost. The important thing was that Elena had a lot of fun running, regardless of whether she won or lost.
texts.sectioneli5-13-3: Elena loves running a lot. She prefers running over watching TV, eating ice cream, or reading books. Running is what she likes most in the world.
texts.sectioneli5-13-4: Elena didn't want to go to her grandpa's house because she thought it would be boring. Her dad reminded her that grandpa has a beautiful garden, trying to make the idea of going more fun. Sometimes, we can find fun things in places we don't expect.
texts.sectioneli5-13-5: Elena is a little upset because she wants to play and her grandfather can't run with her. She thinks that there's only fun with pets or turtles. But her dad tells her that grandpa has amazing books. So, books can also be fun to imagine and learn! 🤓📚
texts.sectioneli5-13-6: Elena's dad tells her that it's okay to go to Grandpa Enrique's house and have fun. He explains that playing and enjoying oneself is important, and that if children don't play on their own when they are young, they might become foolish when they grow up. So he encourages her to go and have a good time.
texts.sectioneli5-14-0: Elena went to her grandfather's house and started running in the garden. At first she was having fun, but then she got bored because she liked more exciting races.
texts.sectioneli5-14-1: Elena's grandfather sees that she is bored and tells her to race against her shadow. At first, Elena is surprised, but then she feels brave and says she is ready to run. It's a fun way to play and feel fast!
texts.sectioneli5-14-2: When the grandfather said 'Ready, go!', they started a super fun race. Everyone ran very, very fast, like when you play running with your friends in the park.
texts.sectioneli5-14-3: Elena was running very fast, almost as fast as a rabbit. But her shadow was also running very fast, like a lion. Although Elena was running a lot, her shadow was always a little ahead. She ran and ran to try to win.
texts.sectioneli5-14-4: Elena was running and wanted to race against her shadow. But, in the end, her shadow was going faster than she was. Elena felt frustrated because she didn't like losing, not even against her own shadow! It's like when we play and don't like to be beaten.
texts.sectioneli5-14-5: Elena's grandfather organized a race. He said: "On your marks, get set, go!" Elena ran very fast, having fun and trying to be faster than her shadow. It was a fun game to run and enjoy outdoors.
texts.sectioneli5-14-6: Elena decided to run very fast, faster than lightning. Her shadow also ran fast, like the clouds in the sky. But, no matter how much the shadow hurried, Elena always went a little bit ahead. In the end, Elena said joyfully: "I won! I am faster than my shadow!"
texts.sectioneli5-15-0: Elena loves winning races. Sometimes she wins and other times she loses, which makes her smile or cry. Her grandfather promises her a magical secret to beat the shadows in a race. This secret is a poem that helps Elena run in a special way. Thus, Elena learns to win in a fun way.
texts.sectioneli5-15-1: When you run under the sun, your shadow is behind you and it seems like it is "nipping" at your heels. If you have the sun in front of you, the shadow lengthens in front of you and it seems like it always wins. It's a fun way to understand how shadows change according to the position of the sun.
texts.sectioneli5-15-2: Elena wanted to win races, and her grandfather taught her a special trick. She learned a poem that told her how to run so her shadow wouldn't win. So, she ran with the sun on her face and always won. In the end, she was very happy and proud of herself.
texts.sectioneli5-15-3: Elena loved winning races. One day, while playing, her grandfather counted 87 of her victories. When night came, the shadows disappeared and Elena no longer had anyone to compete with, so she went into the house. She was so tired after so many games that she fell asleep using a tortilla as a pillow. Then, the grandfather went out and, when the moon appeared, all the shadows returned to the garden. It was a very fun afternoon.
texts.sectioneli5-16-0: Let's get to know Elena. She is a girl who loves to run. She has messy hair because she runs a lot. When she runs, her heart beats very fast. Her legs are super fast, but sometimes she gets injuries on her knees. She wears sports shoes, which help her run better. Now we can imagine what Elena is like.
texts.sectioneli5-16-1: This section tells us about Elena, a girl who loves to run. She has disheveled hair because she is always running very fast. Her knees sometimes get hurt and her heart beats fast when she runs. She wears sneakers to run faster and has very fast legs. Now, using this information, you can write a bit about what Elena is like and what she likes to do.
texts.sectioneli5-17-0: Elena is bored because she has no one to play with. She goes to her grandfather's house, and he suggests that she race against her shadow. Although she doesn't always win at first, her grandfather shares a secret to improve. This way, Elena learns that she can have fun in new and creative ways.
texts.sectioneli5-18-0: This is a story about Elena who spends the night at her grandfather Enrique's house. The grandfather had a fun idea for when she got bored. Elena did something related to "the shadow," but at first, she was annoyed. Then, she learned a special secret that helped her beat the shadow. Completing the story can help practice reading and imagination.
texts.sectioneli5-19-0: In this activity, we have to match phrases with arrows to make complete sentences. It's like putting together pieces of a puzzle to make sense. For example, 'Grandpa Enrique' can be joined with 'counted eighty-seven victories' to form a sentence. This teaches us to create meaningful sentences and understand how words are combined.
texts.sectioneli5-19-1: Here you have to form sentences using parts of speech given to you like puzzle pieces. Then, you put them in order to tell a story. We already have one: "Grandpa Enrique counted eighty-seven victories." This is how a complete story is created step by step.
texts.sectioneli5-19-2: Here you have a fun game. You have to match parts of sentences to make complete sentences. It's a bit like piecing together parts of a puzzle. Then, write the sentences you created using big and beautiful letters called cursive writing. This will help you practice how these special letters are written. It's like drawing words!
texts.sectioneli5-20-0: We have the story of Elena, a girl who loves to run. Her parents take her to her grandfather's house and she doesn't like it much at first. When she arrives at her grandfather's house, she has no one to run with and gets bored. But then, her grandfather challenges her to race against her own shadow, and she accepts; sometimes she wins, sometimes she loses. In the end, her grandfather teaches her a trick to beat the shadow. So, we learn that going to her grandfather's house became something fun for Elena. What do we learn from all this? That sometimes, something that doesn't seem fun at first can turn into a great adventure, especially with a cool grandfather who teaches you new things!
texts.sectioneli5-20-1: Elena is a girl who loves to run, but when she goes to her grandfather's house, she gets bored because she doesn't have anyone to race with. The task is to choose which sentence best tells this part of the story—as when you're asked whether you prefer to play or to be bored studying—here you choose 'Elena's Boredom' because she has no company to run with.
texts.sectioneli5-20-2: This story is about Elena and her grandfather. The grandfather gives her a fun challenge: to race against her shadow. Elena accepts and sometimes wins, sometimes loses. The activity is to choose which phrase best describes what happened: the correct phrase is 'The grandfather's challenge', because it was the grandfather who challenged her to run.
texts.sectioneli5-20-3: In the story, Elena learned a secret from her grandfather to beat her shadow. You have to help choose the best summary of what happened: which of the options best tells what Elena learned? It's a game to better understand the story!
texts.sectioneli5-20-4: Elena went to grandfather's house, got bored, but the grandfather challenged her to a race. She learned a trick to win. So she had a lot of fun in the end.
texts.sectioneli5-21-0:
Here is a fun poem that tells a secret about how to beat the shadows. It says that if you face the sun, the shadow follows you, but it doesn't matter if you run slow (slowly) or fast (light), you will always arrive first.

The question makes you think about the relationship between "slow" and "light." These words are opposites, because "slow" means slow and "light" means fast or quick.
texts.sectioneli5-21-1:
We are going to learn about words that are opposites and those that are similar.

Opposite words are called *antonyms*. For example, if a dog barks *softly*, the opposite is to bark *loudly*. That's how we play with words.

We also have words that mean the same or almost the same, and these are called *synonyms*.

It's like a game of finding which words are opposites and which are the same. Let's fill in the missing ones and learn while having fun!
texts.sectioneli5-22-0: Let's describe Elena's grandfather using comparisons, like when we say something is 'soft as a cloud.' For example, his hair is gray as smoke. Then, use similar comparisons to describe his eyes, lips, hands, and legs. You also need to think about how he is, like cheerful or patient. This helps you practice describing using your imagination.
texts.sectioneli5-22-1: Let's describe Elena's grandfather using comparisons. Imagine him so others can see him in their minds. For example, his hair is gray like smoke, and we continue comparing him with other fun or interesting things. When talking about his hands or what he likes to do, we use creative ideas to make him very special.
texts.sectioneli5-23-0: In this dialogue, the grandfather asks Elena why she is sad and bored. Elena says she has no one to run with. The grandfather suggests that she run against her shadow, as a fun game. It's a way to use imagination to not get bored.
texts.sectioneli5-23-1: Here we have a fun word task. We need to find words that belong to the same family as 'trunk' and 'shadow'. It's like looking for their cousins in the dictionary. Look at the images, like a picture book, and think about what words are related. Use the dictionary if you need help. Have fun exploring words with 'trunk' and 'shadow'! Like it's a game, search and find the hidden words. 😊
texts.sectioneli5-23-2: Here you have a drawing with various things. The activity is to find the objects that have the magical letters 'mp' or 'mb' in their name. Look closely at the drawing, search for those objects, and then write their names. It's like a word treasure hunt with special words.
texts.sectioneli5-24-0: Today we are going to practice how to use short words called "pronouns". These words replace nouns so we don't repeat them too much. For example, if you talk about your "brother", you can use "he". Elena runs very fun races. You can write "he" where it says "brother", "he" for "dog", "she" for "turtle", and "he" for "dad". This way we make the text shorter and easier to read. Let's try it together!
texts.sectioneli5-24-1: In this activity, we are going to change the words we use to talk about people, called pronouns, to the names of those characters. For example, if we say 'she', we will look for who 'she' is in the story and put her name or a description like 'the girl who runs races'. This way, we better understand who we are talking about.
texts.sectioneli5-25-0: The Sun is like a big ball of fire in the sky that gives us light and warmth. There are other things that can also give light, like light bulbs or candles, and those are lights made by us. Most of the things we see do not have their own light; we see them because the light from something like the Sun bounces off them and reaches our eyes.
texts.sectioneli5-25-1:
Imagine there are three types of things: things that don't let light pass through, things that let some light pass through, and things that let all the light through.

Things that don't let light pass through are called opaque, like a cardboard box. These things create shadows.

Then there are translucent things, which let some light pass through, but you cannot see clearly through them, like frosted glass or nylon.

Finally, transparent things let all the light pass through, and you can see clearly through them, like window glass or the lenses people use to see better.
texts.sectioneli5-25-2: Shadows change shape throughout the day because the sun moves across the sky. In the morning, shadows are long; at noon, they are short or disappear; and in the afternoon, they lengthen again. This happens because sunlight travels in a straight line, which changes the shadows depending on where the sun is in the sky.
texts.sectioneli5-25-3: Light comes from the sun and other things like bulbs. When light hits things, they can be three types: opaque, translucent, and transparent. Opaque objects do not let light through and create shadows, like cardboard. Translucent objects let a little light through, like frosted glass. And transparent objects let all the light through, like window glass. Shadows change shape with the sun because light travels in a straight line. In the morning and afternoon, they are long, and at noon, they are short.
texts.sectioneli5-26-0: The text teaches about light and shadow. It tells us that the Sun is like a big natural lamp that gives us light and heat. This is like saying that the Sun is the source or the place from which all the light and heat we feel on Earth come.
texts.sectioneli5-26-1: When we talk about opaque objects, we refer to things that do not let light pass through. Think of them as a wall that does not allow light to pass to the other side, so if something is behind it, it will be in shadow. In the exercise, you must choose the option that says opaque bodies block light.
texts.sectioneli5-26-2: When we think about sunlight, it is important to know that it travels in straight lines, like when you throw a ball in a straight line and it follows its path. This means that light moves directly from the Sun to objects on Earth without making curves.
texts.sectioneli5-27-0: The Sun is a star, which means it is an object in space that shines with its own light. It is what gives us natural light and heat on Earth. There are other lights that humans have created, like light bulbs and candles, which are called artificial lights. Most of the things we see do not shine by themselves; they are visible because they reflect light from something that does, like the Sun.
texts.sectioneli5-27-1: You should rewrite a sentence about the Sun using more information from the notebooks. For example, you could say: "The Sun is a star (that is, a celestial body that shines with its own light)." Use words like "that is" or "in other words" when expanding an idea, and pay close attention to how you use commas and parentheses.
texts.sectioneli5-28-0: In this task, we are going to learn about things that give off light, called light sources. Some are natural, like the sun and the stars, because they are there without us making them. Others are artificial, like a flashlight or an electric lamp, which are things we create to have light. Think about when you see these types of light and how they help us see everything around us.
texts.sectioneli5-28-1: There are different types of light and bodies that let it pass. Light sources can be natural, such as the sun and stars, or artificial, like a lamp or a candle. Opaque bodies do not let light pass through. There are others, like frosted glass, that allow light to pass through and let us see through them clearly.
texts.sectioneli5-29-0: You have to help fix a text that has errors. You need to separate the words that are stuck together, capitalize the beginning of sentences, and use punctuation marks like periods and commas. The image shows how you can use your hands to create shadows on the wall, making shapes like animals. It's very fun to practice! Additionally, it makes it easier to understand how light and shadows work.
texts.sectioneli5-30-0: Chinese shadow puppets are a fun and old game where you use your hands and a light to make figures on the wall. You can make shadows that look like ducks, rabbits, or snakes. If you keep your hands still, the figure doesn't move. But if you move your fingers, the figures can seem to be alive and moving. It's like doing magic with shadows using only your hands.
texts.sectioneli5-30-1: First, read the text about Chinese shadows again. Then, talk to your classmates to see which words are repeated and how to improve the text. After that, write your ideas to change it in a draft and, finally, make your corrected version of the text here.

texts.easyread-text-25-0: An encyclopedia is a big book with lots of facts about different things.
texts.easyread-text-25-1: Light helps us see things. Shadow is dark and made when something blocks the light.
texts.easyread-text-25-2: The Sun is a star. It is a big ball of burning gases.
texts.easyread-text-25-3: It is what gives Earth light and heat.
texts.easyread-text-25-5: Most things we see do not make their own light.
texts.easyread-text-25-6: We can see them because they get light from a bright thing.
texts.easyread-text-25-4: We have other lights like electric lamps and candles. They are not natural lights.
texts.easyread-text-25-7: Light helps us see things. Objects can change how light looks. Some things let light pass through, like windows. Other things stop light, like walls.
texts.easyread-text-25-8: We can sort objects into three groups: some you can't see through at all, some let a little light through, and some you can see through easily.
texts.easyread-text-25-9: Opaque objects, like cardboard, do not let light pass through and make a shadow.
texts.easyread-text-25-10: See-through things let light in but you can't see clearly through them.
texts.easyread-text-25-11: Two examples are frosted glass and nylon.
texts.easyread-text-25-12: Transparent things let light through them, like glass windows and lenses, so you can see clearly through them.
texts.easyread-text-25-13: Shadows are made when something blocks the light. They can change shape depending on how the light hits them.
texts.easyread-text-25-14: The sun changes shadows during the day.
texts.easyread-text-25-15: In the morning, shadows are long. At noon, they get short or go away. In the afternoon, shadows get long again.
texts.easyread-text-25-16: Sunlight travels in straight lines, which makes shadows look bent.
texts.easyread-text-25-17: ProLEE made this notebook using different encyclopedia sources.

texts.easyread-text-26-9: Opaque objects do not let light pass through.
texts.easyread-text-26-12: Opaque things stop light from going through.

texts.easyread-text-28-3: "Natural" means it happens on its own or is found in nature.
texts.easyread-text-28-4: Artificial means something that is made by people, not by nature. For example, a plastic plant is artificial because it is not a real plant.
texts.easyread-text-28-5: Without more information, I can't simplify this text properly. Could you give me more details?
texts.easyread-text-28-6: Stars are lights in the sky at night.
texts.easyread-text-28-7: The word 'vela' can mean two things: a 'candle' you light up or a 'sail' on a boat. If you only see 'vela,' it's hard to know which one it is without more information.
texts.easyread-text-28-8: A lantern is a light you can carry. It helps people see in the dark.
texts.easyread-text-28-9: Fire is something that can be hot and burn things. We use it to keep warm.
texts.easyread-text-28-10: Luciérnagas are bugs that glow in the dark at night.
texts.easyread-text-28-11: "Rays" are like beams of light or energy. Sometimes people also say "rayos" like an expression, similar to "darn". It's like a strong feeling word when something happens.
texts.easyread-text-28-12: An electric lamp is a light that uses electricity to shine.

texts.easyread-text-28-17: Opaco means something you cannot see through. It's like a wall or a door that blocks your view.
texts.easyread-text-28-19: Frosted glass is a type of glass that you can't see through well. It looks cloudy or foggy.
texts.easyread-text-29-6: Steps to make shadow puppets: 1. Get a flashlight. 2. Find a blank wall. 3. Turn off the lights. 4. Shine the flashlight on the wall. 5. Use your hands to make shapes in front of the light. 6. See the shadows on the wall. 7. Try different shapes and have fun!
